moves.1. d4: A rather secure and good opening move.
moves.2. Be3: A bit defensive; a move to the fourth rank is more aggressive and probably better.
moves.3. c3: Bolstering the defensive formation; though White should have moved the knight out first.
moves.3... Nc6: Black remains aggressive, though not stupidly so.
moves.4. h3: Setting up 5.g4 and attacking the bishop.
moves.4... Bg6: Black wants to keep the presence on this diagonal and moves the bishop back to avoid threat of capture.
moves.5. g4: White follows through and attacks the kingside, or at least sets up for it.
moves.5... f6: Black, meanwhile, is looking to expand his center presence.
moves.6. Bg2: White's forces are gathering on the kingside, while Black's forces look rather weak.
moves.7. f4: White wishes to keep his center strong.
moves.7... exf4: Black is trying to get White's forces even more concentrated (and cramped) on one side.
moves.8. Bxf4: White captures and has a decent setup.
moves.8... Be4: Time, now, to start attacking White, or at least blow up the formation.
moves.9. Nf3: White likes his formation and will block the attack, though this does severely limit the scope of the bishop.
moves.9... Bd6: Now the bishop standoff is complete.
moves.10. Be3: White is retreating towards the center.
moves.10... Nge7: Time to get the other pieces involved.
moves.11... Ng6: Black has the bishop protected and wants to get the knight in there.
moves.13. Nh4: A bad move to get the knight out of the way; Nd2 was much better.
moves.13... Nxh4: A break; Black takes the undefended bishop and has good position with his knight to harass White.
moves.14. Bxe4: White needs to get the bishop out of the way and will take the undefended pawn.
moves.14... Qe7: Black sees that the bishop is undefended and will get the queen into the game by threatening both bishops on the file.
moves.15. Bxc6+: That takes care of the one bishop.
moves.16. Bf2: This protects against 16...Bg3+ and attacks the knight.
moves.16... Ng2+: Black takes his other secure check.
moves.17. Kd2: Not a good move; Kf1 would have been much better and would have avoided exposing the king.
moves.18. e3: A decent block, though not ideal.
moves.18... Nxe3: Rather than just check again, the knight attacks the queen and sets up a discovered check.
moves.19. Bxe3: White will part with his last minor piece; he has little choice.
moves.19... Qxe3+: Now Black has infiltrated White's position badly.
moves.20... Qe4+: Black now forces the king to really run away.
moves.22. Kxd3: Again, the only move to be made.
moves.22... O-O: Black doesn't have much opportunity to get great pawn structure and will instead get the rooks going, exploiting the extra piece.
moves.23... Rfe8: Black is perfectly willing to trade pieces away and make the advantage of the extra bishop that much more dramatic.
moves.24. Re4: This move is rather superfluous other than giving White an attack on the bishop.  Not a bad idea though.
moves.25... Bd6: The bishop is moved to safety.
moves.26. b4: Time to get aggressive; the only thing White has left.
moves.26... Re8+: A rather cheap but easy check.
moves.27. Kd3: White will retreat a bit and defend his pawns.
moves.27... a5: Black is looking to eliminate pawns as well.
moves.28. b5: White ought to have taken the a-pawn.
moves.30. Kc4: The king trying to make a move.
moves.31... Re3+: Time to start picking off White's pawns, and this check starts it.
moves.32. Kc4: White is determined not to get pinned back.
moves.32... Re5: Black will set up for his next move.
moves.33. Rb1: White getting ready for some sort of check.
moves.33... c6: Black will give up this pawn as well, knowing he will get it back.
moves.34. dxc6: White will take it and hope for a mistake.
moves.34... Rc5+: And Black does not make one.
moves.36. Kd5: The king needs to attack; waiting around for Black to do something is certain death.
moves.36... Ra6: The only move to save both pieces.
moves.37... g6: Black is looking to take both White pawns on the kingside.
moves.38. h4: White must do something, after all.
moves.40. h5: There is really no other move.
moves.40... Kg7: The king's services are finally needed.
moves.41... Kf6: The king must protect his own pieces.
moves.42. Rxh7: Now White has a possible route to promotion.
moves.44. Rh8: White is not willing to give up his last piece.
moves.45. Rh7: Waiting around and establishing a safe route to the f-file.
moves.45... f2: Forcing White to do something, Black will either get a queen or White's last free pawn.
moves.46... Bg3: A decent defense; Black is toying with White.
moves.47. Ke4: White needs to get the king closer to the action.
moves.48. Rxf6: White resigns himself to his fate.
moves.48... Kxf6: Black has the game by the throat.
moves.49... Kg6: Black won't give up a queen under his nose.
moves.51. Kf3: White will at least get the bishop.
moves.52... Qd1: Black has no interest in a king-and-queen checkmate.
moves.54... Qb3+: Getting out of the way of the pawn.
moves.55. Kd2: Setting himself up for the noose.
moves.56. Kc1: Hoping Black will make a mistake.
moves.59... Qaa2+: Avoids letting the king out and prolonging the game any more.
